Module com.jlbabilino.json
Package com.jlbabilino.json

Annotation Interface DeserializedJSONDeterminer

@Documented @Retention(RUNTIME) @Target(METHOD) public @interface DeserializedJSONDeterminer

Marks a specific type of method in a JSONSerializable interface or abstract class as the "determiner method." The determiner serves as a basic way to achieve polymorphisim in JSON deserialization. When a JSONEntry is deserialized to an interface or abstract class type, the deserializer checks for a method with this annotation and these conditions:

  • The method is static
  • The method has no type parameters.
  • There is exactly one parameter of the appropriate JSONEntry type, meaning that it matches the type of JSON that the interface or abstract class is JSONSerializable to. For example, an interface that is serializable for JSON objects would need this parameter to be of type JSONObject.
  • The return type is TypeMarker.
  • The TypeMarker returned is parameterized, and it follows the format TypeMarker<? extends TYPE>, where TYPE is this abstract class or interface.
  • If this interface or abstract class is generic, the wildcard inside the type marker should extend the interface or abstract class, but it should also be parameterized. The parameters can be of any type, but most of the time they will all be wildcards.
  • The method throws JSONDeserializationException
  • Although it is not checked for, the determiner should not return a TypeMarker that represents the interface or abstract class itselft, as that will cause infinite recursion.

The determiner reads the contents of the JSONEntry and determines the appropriate type that this JSONEntry should be deserialized to, based solely on the JSONEntry, and returns it as a TypeMarker object. Since TypeMarker objects are not dynamic and must be created at compile-time, it is good practice to create all possible type markers as private static final fields containing anonymous inner classes in the interface or abstract class. These can be selected from when the method is invoked. The determiner cannot always make the appropriate choice between these types, as sometimes the JSONEntry is not in the correct format. When this occurs, the method can throw a JSONDeserializationException with a message that will be propogated back to the class that invoked the deserialization method.

The JSONEntry passed into this method by the deserializer will never be null.
